title: 105_hr4201
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" amends the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include Assistant United States Attorneys as law enforcement officers. This Act modifies section 8401 of title 5, United States Code, to define an Assistant United States Attorney as an appointed official under section 542 of title 28. The effective date of this Act and its amendments is specified in section 3. The Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the first pay period after the 90-day period following enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. 
(a) Incumbent Defined.--An incumbent is an individual first appointed as an Assistant United States Attorney before the effective date of this Act and serving in that capacity on such date.
(b) Notice Requirement.--Within 6 months of the effective date, the Department of Justice must notify incumbents of their election rights under this Act.
(c) Election Available to Incumbents.--An incumbent may choose to be treated according to the amendments made by this Act or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to make a timely election has consequences. Failure to timely elect under this subsection is treated as if the election was made on the last allowable day. The election must be made before the 90th day after notice is provided or the incumbent separates from service. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until an election is made. Retroactive effect applies to those who elect the option under subsection (c)(1)(A). The option under subsection (c)(1)(A) allows Assistant United States Attorneys to have their service treated according to the amended provisions of chapter 83 or 84 of title 5, United States Code. Makeup contributions are required from the Department of Justice in addition to other payments under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5. The Department of Justice must remit the specified amount to the Office of Personnel Management, which will then deposit it into the Treasury of the United States for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. This amount includes additional individual and Government contributions that would have been required for Assistant United States Attorneys before their election under subsection (c). The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for the Act, including determining interest on contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined in the section. No individual liability is created for contribution shortfalls under this Act.
